title: Interpreters
description: I'm currently reading the textbook Crafting Interpreters by Robert Nystrom in order to learn how interpreters work under the hood (via parsing, tokenizing, context-free grammars, etc.). Part of the book is building an interpreter with Java for Nystrom's fake programming language Lox, and in the future, using C for more low-level programming instead of Java's high-level features.

title: Shaders
description: In Summer of 2024, I learned from thebookofshaders.com by Patricio Gonzales Vivo and Jen Lowe how to design and code fragment shaders using OpenGL, using techniques like shaping functions, deterministic randomness, cellular noise, and fractal Brownian motion. I programmed Voronoi diagrams, the Mandelbrot set, and various cool-looking motions. Click on the shaders to cycle through some of the ones I made (and try moving your mouse over some!).

title: Infinite Sum Visualizer
description: When I was a kid, I developed a Processing applet with Java to display some infinite sum formula with Complex inputs on the Complex plane. I decided to recently rebuild it using Python for a cleaner look, smoother interactivity, and practice with magic method overloading. The graph is interactable with the radius of convergence plotted as well. Check it out as a Google Colab by clicking the picture, or see the repository itself.

title: This website!
description: I hope you've enjoyed looking at it! I spent a lot of time on it. It's built with React and NodeJS, and it's my first exposure to HTML and CSS. While I have technically used Javascript before, the last time I tried was when var was used to declare variables...so basically brand new to JS too.
